docs.lead_paragraph: Unveiling a book-length plan that hinges on optimistic fiscal forecasts, Vice President Al Gore today offered his economic vision for the future, painting an image of a prosperous middle class that enjoys higher incomes, with more home ownership, more high-tech jobs and more people going to college. ''My cause is hard-working, middle-class families,'' he declared at the start of his speech here today at Cleveland State University.

headline.main: GORE OFFERS VISION OF BETTER TIMES FOR MIDDLE CLASS

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore outlines series of social and economic goals he says are attainable given nation's current prosperity, and he presents mountain of supporting detail intended to make Gov George W Bush's financial plan pale in comparison, speech, Cleveland State University; speech reflects shift in language and approach for Gore, who now speaks of 'middle-class families' rather than 'working families'; Gore's booklength economic blueprint reignites debate with Bush over whose plan can best manage projected budget surplus over next decade without ruining economy; Bush says Gore's many spending promises would eat through surplus; Gore, hoping to deflect such perception, pledges to set aside $300 billion as hedge against overly optimistic fiscal projections; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Tired of wearing those unwieldy eyeglasses? Sick of messing with contact lenses? Try getting a job with the city of Hartford, and your troubles could soon be over. Hartford, it turns out, is the only large city in Connecticut, and possibly in the New York metropolitan region, that offers its employees full coverage for cosmetic laser eye surgery, a perk that could end up costing the struggling city millions.

headline.main: Hartford Counts Up the Costs of a Vision Plan

docs.abstract: Hartford, Conn, officials discusses city offering its employees full coverage for cosmetic laser eye surge; cost of benefit noted (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ROCCO arrived for physical therapy at Bonnie's K9 Swim Center in Manhattan, prancing with excitement, a bandana knotted around his thick furry neck and metal wheels strapped to his withered hind legs. Rocco, a 10-year-old German shepherd, had lymphoma last summer, followed by a ruptured disk requiring emergency surgery. In a gesture of paternal tenderness combined with the umph of a furniture mover on the last landing, Lenny Addamo, Rocco's owner, lowered the 90-pound dog into the waiting arms of Jodi Richard, who was already submerged to her shoulders in 87-degree water and ready to right Rocco adroitly as he started to roll and submerge. The pool's surface, lightly dusted with dog hair, boiled around Rocco's flailing front paws as Ms. Richard, the owner of Bonnie's K9, a new therapy center for dogs, held on to his hips.
docs.abstract: Pets are being pampered with luxuries like physical therapy as booming economy creates more discretionary income; pet offer same therapies available to humans and are only beginning to meet demand of pet owners eager not only to indulge but also to save their animals; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The television cameras and reporters raced across the marble lobby of the Waldorf-Astoria and swarmed around the Chinese man in a dark suit. Was he a high-ranking party official? Perhaps President Jiang Zemin himself? Hardly. It was William Chiu, chairman of the American Fujian Association of Commerce and Industry. He had just left a meeting with President Jiang. On Tuesday morning, more than 300 Chinese-American community leaders, businessmen and scholars gathered at the hotel to hobnob with the leader of the world's most populous country. About a third were from the New York area.

headline.main: Summit Watching: Who Was That Man in the Suit?
headline.kicker: SUMMIT IN NEW YORK: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK

docs.lead_paragraph: Uh-oh. George W. Bush has come up with a plan to overhaul Medicare.
docs.abstract: Bob Herbert Op-Ed column says Gov George W Bush's plan to overhaul Medicare was probably prompted by polls showing that Vice Pres Al Gore was scoring points with his prescription drug proposal; says Bush's better-late-than-never plan would turn many certainties of Medicare over to whims of profit-oriented insurance companies and health maintenance organizations; suggests that Bush is following through on Republicans' decades-long dream of thoroughly undermining Medicare (M)
docs.snippet: Uh-oh.    George W. Bush has come up with a plan to overhaul Medicare.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George W. Bush announced a proposal on Tuesday to provide prescription drug benefits as an option under comprehensive Medicare reform. But since he does not expect such reform to happen anytime soon, he wants state governments to deal with the problem while a new White House task force works out the details of future reforms. Mr. Bush, like Vice President Al Gore, hopes to court elderly voters with a plan to help pay for the escalating costs of drugs. But unlike Mr. Gore, Mr. Bush would not create a universal drug benefit for all retirees under Medicare. Instead he lays out a rough Medicare reform plan, with few details, that may or may not make drug coverage more accessible in the future. The Bush plan is inferior because it relies on uncertain action by states and the private sector, and would leave too many people without coverage for now.
docs.abstract: Editorial says Gov George W Bush's proposal to provide prescription drug benefits as option under comprehensive Medicare reform may or may not make drug coverage more accessible in future; says Bush's plan is inferior to Vice Pres Al Gore's because it relies on uncertain action by states and private sector, and would leave too many people without coverage for now

docs.lead_paragraph: Perry Nagle, 35, a lawyer specializing in corporate finance, is taking the rest of the year off. Having already earned more than enough money to tide him over until next year, he has packed his bags and is heading for the beaches of Indonesia where, he said, the ocean is ''bath-water warm.'' ''One of my goals for the year is to get in two good months of surfing on the south coast of Java,'' Mr. Nagle said.

headline.main: It's Fall, Time to Hunker Down

docs.abstract: Soaring salaries and tight labor market are enabling some lawyers to choose to work only few months each year or few days a week; Perry Nagle comments on taking advantage of New York's growing market for alternative-work arrangements to pursue outside interests; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from remarks prepared for delivery today by Gov. George W. Bush in Allentown, Pa., announcing his plans for revising Medicare: When Medicare was passed in 1965, President Lyndon Johnson said: ''No longer will older Americans be denied the healing miracle of modern medicine. No longer will illness crush and destroy the savings that they have so carefully put away over a lifetime so that they might enjoy dignity in their later years.''

docs.lead_paragraph: The Democratic National Committee announced yesterday that it would begin running a new commercial tomorrow that takes a critical look at Gov. George W. Bush's record of providing health care for children in Texas. The 30-second spot is to run in nine states that Democrats and Republicans have focused on most heavily : Arkansas, Delaware, Louisiana, Michigan, Missouri, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Washington and Wisconsin. PRODUCER -- Democratic Victory 2000.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George W. Bush's proposal to redesign Medicare and offer drug benefits to the elderly puts him squarely in line with his party's drive to reshape the program by reducing the role of government, increasing the role of insurance companies and giving elderly people more choices. The proposal is also meant to serve an important political purpose: to fend off attacks by Democrats who contend that Mr. Bush has no true commitment to elderly people squeezed by rising drug costs. The elderly, long a key part of the Democratic coalition, are considered a crucial swing vote this year.
